Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Integrative Approach to Understanding and Communicating Evolution in Action
Award.AbstractNarration:
How quickly can new species form, and how predictable is evolution in nature? This project will address these questions in an ideal setting to study evolution in action. Multiple lizard species have evolved white coloration for camouflage in the gypsum dunes of White Sands, New Mexico. These species are undergoing the process of speciation on an extraordinarily rapid timescale. This project will illuminate the factors that accelerate the process of speciation in White Sands lizards. Field studies in nature and genetics studies in the lab will be used to understand how natural selection can lead so quickly to adaptation and speciation.

The white lizards at White Sands provide a compelling, accessible example of evolution and represent a tremendous opportunity for research and public outreach. From an educational perspective this grant will increase scientific literacy and demystify evolutionary concepts for the public. The research will be integrated with educational outreach activities that use the dramatic landscape of White Sands to teach evolutionary biology to the general public. Outreach activities include offering a short "lizard camp" for elementary school children, developing a bilingual English-Spanish museum exhibit about evolution, and disseminating research results in textbooks, magazines and in the popular press.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do new species form? The White Sands of New Mexico provide an ideal environment to understand the early stages of the speciation process. Three lizard species have undergone rapid evolution in this novel habitat. This CAREER grant focused on the factors that can accelerate - or limit - the process of speciation. The Principal Investigator (PI) used a diversity of approaches to understand the genetics, behavior, ecology, and evolution of White Sands lizards. The results demonstrate that speciation can proceed rapidly when natural selection is multidimensional, when natural and sexual selection interact, and when adaptive traits have a simple genetic basis. The impact of this research is to deepen our understanding of fundamental processes that impact the biological diversity on our planet. The grant led to more than a dozen peer-reviewed publications in high-impact journals.

This CAREER grant also focused on science education, specifically communicating evolutionary concepts to broad audiences, focusing on “Evolution in Action”—clear examples of evolutionary change over short, observable timescales. The educational initiatives of the project reached the general public through bilingual interpretive exhibits at White Sands National Monument, elementary school students through a "Lizard Camp" offered every summer, and college students through inclusion in textbooks. The PI is also highly engaged in activities to broaden participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences and offers research training opportunities to minority students and regular workshops on themes of diversity and inclusion. Finally this project has relevance for the conservation and management of biological diversity.
